Description: Tondo sherd of Attic, probably bilingual, pottery eye-cup; interior: outer area glazed black with part of incised inscription; reserved tondo with thin black band encircling figure; black-figure head of a youth to left, with first growth of beard and moustache; added red wreath, part of cloak on shoulders, with added red; red dots on the same or on a chiton underneath; exterior glazed black.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd is also published in Cohen, B., Attic Bilingual Vases. New York 1978, 363, no. B68 and Harnecker, J., Oltos, Untersuchungen zur Themenwahl eines fruehrotfigurigen Schalenmalers. Frankfurt 1992, 197, pl.12, no.A1. Beazley suggests that the youth may be Paris, declining to judge. Harnecker does not agree with this description, as too little of the figure remains to be able to recognise what he is doing.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 434, no. B699)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 236, no. 3)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 709, no. 682, pl. 26.5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0606) (Phase 1)
ARV / Attic Red-Figure Vase-Painters (p. 42, no. 53) (and p. 56, no. 29)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
